fields.body:
4.25pm BST

Closing summary

Time to wrap up.

A blizzard of economic data has highlighted problems in the UK economy today.

Growth over the last 12 months has been revised down to just 1.5%, the lowest since 2013, despite a pick-up in business investment.

The UKâ€™s current account deficit also widened, to over Â£23bn, consumer credit has risen, and service sector growth seems to have cooled sharply in July.

Jon Cunliffe, Chief Investment Officer of Charles Stanley, says:

â€œThe deterioration in the UKâ€™s current account position is disappointing, as it underlines that the sharp devaluation in Sterling has not fed through into a better trade position with the rest of the world.

Analysts have also been predicting that Londonâ€™s housing market has hit a turning point, after prices fell by 0.6% over the last quarter. Details start here.

Bank of England governor Mark Carney has had another busy day, telling the Today Programme that consumer debt is a concern, and that the Bank canâ€™t fix inequality (even though its monetary policy has distributive effects).

He also repeated his warnings that borrowing costs could rise soon:

Related: Bank of England governor gives fresh hint interest rates will rise

Carney has also pledged to improve the bankâ€™s communications.....and been chastised by the chief economist of Citigroup for sticking his oar into the Scottish and Brexit referendums.

Christine Lagarde, meanwhile, has predicted a world where digital currencies challenge traditional ones, and artificial intelligence plays a greater role in running our central banks.

In the City, the FTSE 100 has jumped by around 0.75% today, while the pound has dipped to $1.341 following the growth downgrade.

Thatâ€™s all for this week. Thanks for reading and commenting. GW

3.57pm BST

Carney: We need to communicate better

We need to make the Bank of England more permeable and comprehensible, Mark Carney concludes, so that the public understands what itâ€™s up to.

He admits that a middle-aged man in a blue suit reading out a speech simply doesnâ€™t cut it these day (even though thatâ€™s exactly what Carney is doing right now).

The Bank is trying to reach out to the public; officials have met 10,000 people at regional meetings, and itâ€™s holding a series of Town Hall events too.

It has also racked up one million hits to its Bank Underground blog (which is well worth checking out)

But....Carney says the BoE must do more, and use social media to keep the public better informed.

We need to do a much better job of taking bite-sized bits of analysis, cut them and send them out so people can grab them understand what the trade-offs are in monetary policy, why the Phillips Curve has gone down...

How much capital the banks really do have, and if house prices go down by a third what would happen to the banking sector.

Some of it will be good, some of it will be incomprehensibly impermeable.

At least Carney isnâ€™t setting the bar unrealistically high....

3.36pm BST

Carney then explains why he doesnâ€™t support calls for a new strategic body, involving the Treasury, to oversee systemic risk issues.

Our current arrangement does involve picking up the phone when the chancellor phones...and phoning him up too when thereâ€™s a financial stability problem, says Carney.

Plus, the Bank must tell the government if it thinks taxpayers funds are at risk.

3.30pm BST

Mark Carney is wrapping up his two-conference on central bank independence now.

Governor Carney says the consensus from the meeting is that Bank of England independence has worked, but with several buts.

One is that Britain hasnâ€™t yet tackled the â€˜too big to failâ€™ problem â€“ the fact that our largest banks would still need to be bailed out if they collapse.

Carney says:

Everywhere Iâ€™m asked, when are we going to tackle the â€˜too big to failâ€™ problem, and its fundamental unfairness.

He explains that the Bank has all the tools it needs, but it hasnâ€™t yet completed the job.

Carney also responds to Willem Buiterâ€™s scorching criticism of meddling central bankers, arguing that the Bank had a legal responsibility to express concerns over the 2014 Scottish independence referendum.

If youâ€™re testifying at parliament and MPs ask you if Scottish independence has financial stability risks, â€˜you canâ€™t dodge itâ€™, says Carney.

2.54pm BST

Professor Ngaire Woods of Oxford University takes issue with Willem Buiterâ€™s comments that central bankers should stick to monetary policy.

She warns that this will simply make the Bank of England look remote and uncaring.

The problem with a strict interpretation [of a central bank mandate] is that central banks will look like what most of the people in most countries think the elite look like -- people who are just not listening.

Financial crises have led to the rise of the far-right, so itâ€™s really important that the Bank shows that it is listening to peopleâ€™s concerns, she adds.

2.51pm BST

Clearly no-one told Willem Buiter that the Bank of England is having a celebration this week....

2.36pm BST

Buiter blasts central bankers

Back at the Bank of Englandâ€™s conference, Citigroupâ€™s Willem Buiter is delivering a forensic explanation of central bankersâ€™ failings since the financial crisis began.

Buiter says central bank independence is under threat because the bankers themselves have failed to â€˜stick to their knittingâ€™, and instead have got involved in politics.

He accuses them of becoming â€œpartizansâ€� in the debate on fiscal policy, structural reforms, and inequality, including:

  • the ECBâ€™s â€œextraordinaryâ€� intervention in the Irish banking crisis, when Jean-Claude Trichet wrote to the Irish finance minister and effectively dictated fiscal policy.
  • Mario Draghiâ€™s repeated calls for structural reforms in the eurozone
  • The Bank of Englandâ€™s comments on Brexit, which received â€œa very heated response from some of the Brexiteersâ€�.
  • Trichet and Draghiâ€™s active role in the downfall of Italian PM Silvio Berlusconi

This is compounded by the failure of monetary policy to do better since the financial crisis, Buiter continues. He says:

Central banks have some output legitimacy, but have very little input legitimacy.

And there is simply not enough accountability at some institutions. The ECB, for example, should start holding a formal vote at its meetings, and publish the results.

Updated at 2.37pm BST

2.06pm BST

This drop in London house prices could be a â€œmilestoneâ€� for prices in the capital, says Vicky Fowler, partner at law firm Gowling WLG.

She believes that falling real wages are to blame, rather than an exodus of overseas buyers.

Fowler explains:

A recent Mayoral report highlighted that overseas investors count for just one in ten of the central London properties in current ownership. Recent figures highlighting a widespread decrease in wage levels throughout the UK could, therefore, be having more of an effect on the capitalâ€™s property market than originally thought.

â€œIndeed, with Sadiq Khan having recently committed to the building of more affordable homes, one wonders if this could be the beginning of a downward trend where the proportion of Londonâ€™s properly affordable homes grows significantly and a corresponding downward pressure on land valuesâ€�.

1.44pm BST

I missed this earlier (under the deluge of UK data), but eurozone inflation has come in below forecasts this month.

Eurostatâ€™s â€˜flashâ€™ estimate shows that prices in the euro area only rose by 1.5% in September, the same as in August. Economists had expected a rise to 1.6%.

More significantly, core inflation (stripping out food and energy) fell from 1.2% to 1.1%.

That means the European Central Bankâ€™s money-printing stimulus programme isnâ€™t having the effect Mario Draghi hoped for - so the ECB will probably keep printing for longer!

1.10pm BST

Looking back at house prices... this charts shows how London properties are still waaaay beyond the average earner, despite dropping 0.6% over the last year.

Updated at 1.27pm BST

12.52pm BST

Christine Lagarde is also asked whether digital currencies could eventually mean that monetary policy becomes redundant.

Q: If currencies are truly global...could we reach a point where exchange rate targeting is necessary as thatâ€™s the only way that markets can decide the strength of a countryâ€™s economy?

Lagarde argues that in the short term, the fragmentation of the financial world makes central bankers more necessary.

But eventually - who will set the value of money? The future will tell. Que sera sera, Lagarde smiles.

12.46pm BST

Back on digital currencies....Christine Lagarde suggests that they could be included in the IMFâ€™s own basket of currencies, its â€˜special drawing rightsâ€™.

12.35pm BST

Lagarde warns that policymakers must remember that new technologies must work for all.

This was neglected when everyone was â€œbeating their chestsâ€� about how globalisation was helping the world economy to grow.

Let us make sure that these new technologies, and the way they will adapt the world economy, will benefit everyone, she concludes. Otherwise, by 2050 we might be â€œvery sorryâ€� that we didnâ€™t remind ourselves of that today.

12.28pm BST

Lagarde: Prepare for more AI in central banking

Christine Lagarde also predicts a day when artificial intelligence plays a much bigger role in running the economy.

She tells the Bank of England conference that artificial intelligence is improving fast. Even the worldâ€™s best Go players have found themselves outmatched by computers, who could self-learn and develop better strategies.

In a few decades time, we might find that smart machines are helping to run our central banks too.

Lagarde says:

Clearly the global economy is vastly more complex than a game of Go. But over the next generation machines will almost certainly play a much larger role in assisting policymakers offering realtime forecasts, spotting bubbles and uncovering complex financial links.

Young economists shouldnâ€™t cry into their spreadsheets too much, though. Lagarde says humans will still be needed to run the system.

And she also warns that the public may find it hard to trust computers - and could computers explain their decisions in plain English (something existing human central bankers have struggled with....).

As Lagarde puts it:

â€œEven with the best algorithms and machines, targets will be missed, crises will occur, mistakes will be made. But can machines really be held accountable â€” to the young couple unable to buy a house, to the working mother finding herself unemployed?

Updated at 1.02pm BST

12.23pm BST

Lagarde: Central banks must pay attention to digital currencies

Christine Lagarde, the head of the International Monetary Fund, has warned central bankers not to close their eyes and ears to the rise of digital currencies.

Sheâ€™s giving a speech on what the global economy will look like in 20 years, at the Bank of Englandâ€™s conference on central bank independence in London today.

Lagarde says that digital currencies, such as Bitcoin, donâ€™t pose a major threat to the current status quo of fiat currencies today.

Digital currencies are â€œtoo volatile, too risky, too energy-intensiveâ€� to replace traditional currencies today, she argues. Theyâ€™re not scalable enough, theyâ€™re too opaque for regulators to get a grip on, and some have been hacked (for example, the Mt Gox bitcoin exchange which failed in 2014).

But....in 20 years, this situation may have changed, says Lagarde. Eventually, digital currencies could become safer and more reliable, especially in less stable regions.

The IMF chief predicts:

â€œSo in many ways, virtual currencies might just give existing currencies and monetary policy a run for their money.

Central banks such as the BoE need to stay alert, for the moment when a digital currency â€œknocks on the doorâ€� and expects to be treated like sterling.

Updated at 12.25pm BST

11.50am BST

Sterling has fallen, following the news that Britainâ€™s economy grew slower than expected over the last year.

The pound has dropped by over half a cent against the US dollar to $1.338, which is nearly a two-week low.

Thatâ€™s despite Mark Carneyâ€™s latest hint that interest rates will probably rise soon.

Craig Erlam, senior market analyst at OANDA, says this morningâ€™s growth figures have hit sentiment in the City.

Softer GDP data for the second quarter of 1.5%, down from previous estimates of 1.7%, triggered the slide in the pound, which was already looking a little vulnerable following recent moves.

Concerns over the ongoing Brexit talks may also be hitting the pound. Earlier today, European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker warned that it will take â€œmiraclesâ€� for the two sides to start discussing their future relationship next month.

Updated at 11.53am BST

10.58am BST

Adam Posen, a former Bank of England policymaker, says central bankers cannot ignore the fact that they make us all richer, or poorer, by their actions.

Posen was speaking at the Bankâ€™s conference on independence (you can follow it live, here).

Heâ€™s not responding directly to Mark Carneyâ€™s comments on inequality (details here), but heâ€™s put his finger on the underlying issue. Namely, monetary policy has distributional effects.

Carneyâ€™s argument is that itâ€™s up to governments to address that - most likely by changing the tax rate to claw back money from wealthier citizens who benefit when the Bank drives up asset prices through its QE asset purchase scheme.

Posen says that central bankers have to be open about the fact that they are making a choice between inflation and unemployment when they set interest rates. Monetary policy dictates how fast prices rise, or how many more people join the ranks of the unemployed.

For 20 or 30 years, Posen says, central bankers have â€œgot away with arguing that they only focus on aggregatesâ€� - ie, the overall impact of their policies.

But that era is over; if central bankers want to keep the publicâ€™s support, they need to be more explicit about the impact of their actions.

Monetary policy does have its limits, of course; Posen also reminds us that some central bankers are looking to governments to do more.

Posen wraps up with this quote from Jane Austen (who now appears on the new Â£10).

10.11am BST

In more disappointing news, the UKâ€™s current account deficit has widened (yes, thereâ€™s a lot of data out this morning).

The ONS reports that the current account deficit jumped to Â£23.2bn in April to June, up from Â£22.3bn in January to March.

This was mainly caused by a rise in foreign earnings on investment in the UK, which is growing faster than Britainâ€™s own earnings overseas.

The trade deficit narrowed, though, to Â£6.5bn thanks to a rise in exports.

10.04am BST

New figures also show that Britainâ€™s consumers continue to ramp up their borrowings.

Figures show that consumer credit jumped by Â£1.58bn in August, up from Â£1.2bn in July.

This may alarm Mark Carney given his comments about â€˜frothyâ€™ debt this morning.

It suggests more people are turning to credit to finance new purchases, or to cover the gap between wages and inflation.

Updated at 4.11pm BST

9.49am BST

Worryingly, the ONS also warns that Britainâ€™s service sector had a bad July, with its â€œIndex of Servicesâ€� decreasing by 0.2% during the month.

The ONS says:

  • The largest contribution to the month-on-month decrease came from the transport, storage and communication sector, which contributed negative 0.22 percentage points
  • The industry largely responsible for the fall on the month was motion pictures, which contributed negative 0.19 percentage points; this decrease follows a particularly strong June for the industry.

9.42am BST

These new UK growth figures also show that business investment has picked up, but the economy is still barely growing once you adjust for population changes.

Hereâ€™s som key points:

  • GDP per head grew by 0.1% in April-June, much slower than the headline growth of 0.3%
  • Business investment rose by 0.5% during the quarter (revised up from 0%).
  • Household spending rose by 0.2% (revised up from 0.1%)
  • The Household Savings Ratio rose to 5.4%, highest since Q3 2016

9.35am BST

UK annual growth rate cut

Breaking: Britainâ€™s annual growth rate has been revised down.

UK GDP rose by just 1.5% annually in the second quarter of 2017, new figures from the Office for National Statistics show. Thatâ€™s down from an earlier estimate of 1.7%, and is the slowest annual growth since 2013.

However, growth during the quarter was unrevised, at 0.3%. The service sector was the only part of the economy that grew.

More to follow....

Updated at 9.37am BST

9.16am BST

Brexit has helped to push Londonâ€™s housing market to an â€˜inflection pointâ€™, says Nicholas Finn, executive director of Garrington Property Finders.

â€œThe softening of prices was initially led by the capitalâ€™s prime market, which was knocked sideways both by Brexit and in the wake of the introduction of higher rates of stamp duty for high-value homes.

â€œBut it is now spreading from the central boroughs â€“ which saw prices rise fastest during the boom â€“ to other areas where the growth came later.

â€œAs a result the market is at an inflection point, as the froth evaporates and prices gently correct to more realistic levels.

9.13am BST

The decline in London house prices will make it a little easier for people to break into the housing market (although with average prices of Â£471,761, the capital is well beyond most pay packets).

Hereâ€™s Hannah Maundrell, editor in chief of money.co.uk, says:

â€œThe market seems to be cooling slightly in London which will hopefully give people more of a chance to get on the housing ladder â€“ despite still being the most expensive region.

â€œPrices are still on the rise for the rest of the country, with the East Midlands seeing the greatest price increase. Itâ€™s important here to make sure you do your research before you buy to get the best deal.

9.08am BST

Here are some more charts from the Nationwide house price survey (details start here, if youâ€™re just joining us)

Updated at 9.08am BST

9.02am BST

Carney: We can't fix inequality

Mark Carney also insists that the Bank of England isnâ€™t to blame for economic inequality.

Asked if capitalism is broken, the BoE governor tells the Today Programme there are two foundations of prosperity - price stability (steady inflation), and financial stability (banks that donâ€™t blow up).

The gap between rich and poor are crucial issues, but these are issues for the government and broader society. They are not the responsibility of the Bank of England.

The BoEâ€™s job is to use its toolkit to prevent another financial crisis, Carney continues:

The people who get hurt when inflation goes up, or banks go down, are the poorest people in society. Without question, time and time again.

Our job is to make sure that doesnâ€™t happen, then the taxpayer doesnâ€™t have to bailout someone in the City.

There are a host of other things that need to happen to growth the economy, and then society has to decide how to distribute the gains of that growth, not the Bank of England.

Updated at 9.02am BST

8.47am BST

Mark Carney: We're worried about frothy consumer debt

Mark Carney, governor of the Bank of England, has just gone a few rounds with John Humphrys on the Today Programme.

Carney has given another hint that UK interest rates could rise â€œin the coming monthsâ€�, if the economy continues on its current course.

Q: So what effect will this have on people ladled with debt - weâ€™ve got a debt bubble building?

Carney insists that Britain isnâ€™t experiencing another debt bubble, pointing out that households have deleveraged since the financial crisis.

But, the overall level of debt is now rising (in line with GDP) , and the Bank is increasingly concerned that banks are shifting from responsible lending to reckless lending.

Some lending to consumers is getting â€œa little frothy and should be addressedâ€�, Carney says sternly.

He cites a â€œpocket of consumer debtâ€�, including credit card debts, debt for cars and personal loans, which is growing at 10% per year.

Carney says many of these loans are to higher-quality borrowers than before, but still....

We think banks have been giving too much credit for a relatively good economic environment, and not being as disciplined as they should be about their underwriting standards and their pricing on this debt.

In other words, banks arenâ€™t being prudent enough, and making loans that would turn sour if the economy hits trouble.

Carney also rejected calls from former PM Gordon Brown for a new supervisory board to help the Bank handle systemic risks.

He argues that the current system of Bank independence is â€œincredibly well designedâ€�, letting Carney and his colleagues support financial stability and keep banks supporting the economy.

We have a responsibility to identify risks across the economy â€” and come on the Today Programme, go round the country, and highlight where there are emerging vulnerabilities.

Hopefully we have powers to deal with them, but at least we have to surface them.

8.21am BST

Londonâ€™s â€˜unsustainableâ€™ house price boom is over, and not before time, says Alex Gosling, CEO of online estate agents HouseSimple.com.

The London property market has enjoyed almost a decade of phenomenal growth. But year after year of double digit growth was unsustainable and inevitably going to come to an end at some point. That point looks like now.â€�

The Governmentâ€™s reform of the stamp duty bands and the introduction of a second home stamp duty surcharge have hit the London housing market more than any other region.

Brexit fears are also scaring off overseas investors who came to the rescue and supported the London market during the dark years after the financial crash.

Many Londoners will actually be hoping that house prices continue to fall until they reach an affordable level, Gosling continues.

Their wish may well come true.â€�

8.16am BST

This chart from housing expert Neal Hudson shows how the UK housing market has cooled this year.

Updated at 8.16am BST

8.02am BST

Gap between North and South narrows

Nationwide also reports that prices in the North of England are rising faster than in the South.

And not before time, arguably, as the gap has doubled over last 10 years. It now costs an extra Â£171,000 buy a house in the South of England.

Updated at 8.03am BST

7.58am BST

The real shock isnâ€™t that London house prices are falling, itâ€™s that they rose so high for so long.

So argues Lee James Pendleton, head of independent estate agents James Pendleton. He hopes that a drop in prices will help more people into the market.

â€œLondon has been the torchbearer of quite unbelievable growth in recent years but it has been an overvalued market for at least the last three years.

â€œThis shows vendors and agents are becoming more realistic but youâ€™ve got to use an agent that is going to tell you what you need hear. People have got so used to prices going up and the result is too many people have been priced out. London cooling is going to really engage buyers and put us on a better, more stable footing towards the end of the year.

7.55am BST

Jonathan Samuels, CEO of property lender, Octane Capital, reckons a correction to London prices was overdue.

â€œThe London property market has been the victim of its own extraordinary success.

Prices in the capital rose to such a level that a correction was always on the cards.

Extreme supply issues within the M25 coupled with always-on demand will mean the London market can only fall so much. â€œIn reality the ongoing correction will be a positive in the longer term. Even by London standards, prices in some areas of the capital had become frankly absurd.

7.53am BST

Jeremy Leaf, a north London estate agent, says house prices in London are now falling because they rose beyond the reach of most people.

Plus, potential buyers are also cautious because the Bank of England may raise interest rates soon. Brexit doesnâ€™t help, either.

Leaf says:

The London market is struggling for mainly affordability reasons and it is only those sellers who recognise the changed market conditions that are doing deals.
